contentrichtext.text: [[File:Duque-de-Luynes.JPG|thumb|right|210px|The first duke of Luynes]] '''Charles d'Albert, Duke of Luynes''' (5 August 1578 – [[Longueville, Lot-et-Garonne|Longueville]], 15 December 1621), was a [[favourite]] of [[Louis XIII of France|Louis XIII]] who was made a [[Peer of France]] and [[Constable of France]] before dying at the height of his influence. ==Biography== He was the first son of Honoré d'Albert (d. 1592), ''seigneur'' de [[Dukes of Luynes|Luynes]], who was in the service of the three last [[Valois Dynasty|Valois]] kings and of [[Henry IV of France]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=147}} Charles was brought up at court and attended the [[Dauphin of France|dauphin]], later Louis XIII. The king shared his fondness for hunting and rapidly advanced him in favour. In 1615 he was appointed commander of the [[Louvre Palace]] and counsellor, and the following year [[Grand Falconer of France]]. He used his influence over the king in the court intrigues against the queen-mother [[Marie de' Medici]] and her favourite [[Concino Concini|Concini]]. It was Luynes who, with Vitry, captain of the guard, arranged the plot that ended in Concini's assassination (1617) and secured all the latter's possessions in [[Italy]] and France.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=147}} In the same year he was appointed captain of the [[Bastille]] and lieutenant-general of [[Normandy]], and married [[Marie de Rohan]], daughter of the [[duke of Montbazon]]. He employed extreme measures against the [[pamphlet]]eers of the time, but sought peace in Italy and with the [[Protestants]]. In 1619 he negotiated the [[Treaty of Angoulême]] by which Marie de' Medici was accorded complete liberty. He was made governor of [[Picardy]] in 1619; suppressed an uprising of nobles in 1620; and in 1621, with slight military ability or achievement, was appointed [[constable of France]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=147}} His rapid rise to power made him a host of enemies, who looked upon him as but a second Concini. In order to justify his newly-won laurels, Luynes undertook an expedition against the Protestants, but died of a fever in the midst of the campaign, at [[Longueville]] in [[Guienne]], on 15 December 1621.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=147}} ==Family== {{main|Dukes of Luynes}} His brother [[Honoré d'Albert (1581-1649)]], first [[duke of Chaulnes]], was governor of [[Picardy]] and [[Marshal of France]] (1619), and defended his province successfully in 1625 and 1635.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911|p=147}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{EB1911|title=Luynes|volume=17|p=147|url=http://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri17chisrich#page/147/mode/1up}} ==Further reading == *Recommended reading (in chronological order) at the end of the Encyclopædia Britannica (11th ed): **{{Cite book |title=Recueil des pieces plus curieuses qui ent este faites pendant le regne du connestable M. de Luynes|edition=2nd |year= 1624}} **{{Cite book |authorlink=Michel Le Vassor |author=Le Vassor |title=Histoire de Louis XIII |location=Paris|year=1757}} **{{Cite book|authorlink=Henri Griffet|author=Griffet |title=Histoire du regne de Louis XIII, roi de France et de Navarre |location=Paris |year=1758}} **{{Cite journal|author=V.
